trans-unit.source: How to use Hudson with the Azure Blob service | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use Hudson with the Azure Blob service | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Describes how to use Hudson with Azure Blob storage as a repository for build artifacts.
trans-unit.target: Describes how to use Hudson with Azure Blob storage as a repository for build artifacts.

trans-unit.source: Using Azure Storage with a Hudson Continuous Integration solution
trans-unit.target: Using Azure Storage with a Hudson Continuous Integration solution

trans-unit.source: *By <link><linkText>Microsoft Open Technologies Inc.[ms-open-tech]</linkText><title></title></link>*
trans-unit.target: *By <link><linkText>Microsoft Open Technologies Inc.[ms-open-tech]</linkText><title></title></link>*

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: The following information shows how to use the Azure Blob service as a repository of build artifacts created by a Hudson Continuous Integration (CI) solution, or as a source of downloadable files to be used in a build process.
trans-unit.target: The following information shows how to use the Azure Blob service as a repository of build artifacts created by a Hudson Continuous Integration (CI) solution, or as a source of downloadable files to be used in a build process.

trans-unit.source: One of the scenarios where you would find this useful is when you're coding in an agile development environment (using Java or other languages), builds are running based on continuous integration, and you need a repository for your build artifacts, so that you could, for example, share them with other organization members, your customers, or maintain an archive.
trans-unit.target: One of the scenarios where you would find this useful is when you're coding in an agile development environment (using Java or other languages), builds are running based on continuous integration, and you need a repository for your build artifacts, so that you could, for example, share them with other organization members, your customers, or maintain an archive.

trans-unit.source: Another scenario is when your build job itself requires other files, for example, dependencies to download as part of the build input.
trans-unit.target: Another scenario is when your build job itself requires other files, for example, dependencies to download as part of the build input.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial you will be using the Azure Storage Plugin for Hudson CI made available by Microsoft Open Technologies, Inc.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial you will be using the Azure Storage Plugin for Hudson CI made available by Microsoft Open Technologies, Inc.

trans-unit.source: Introduction to Hudson
trans-unit.target: Introduction to Hudson

trans-unit.source: Hudson enables continuous integration of a software project by allowing developers to easily integrate their code changes and have builds produced automatically and frequently, thereby increasing the productivity of the developers.
trans-unit.target: Hudson enables continuous integration of a software project by allowing developers to easily integrate their code changes and have builds produced automatically and frequently, thereby increasing the productivity of the developers.

trans-unit.source: Builds are versioned, and build artifacts can be uploaded to various repositories.
trans-unit.target: Builds are versioned, and build artifacts can be uploaded to various repositories.

trans-unit.source: This topic will show how to use Azure blob storage as the repository of the build artifacts.
trans-unit.target: This topic will show how to use Azure blob storage as the repository of the build artifacts.

trans-unit.source: It will also show how to download dependencies from Azure blob storage.
trans-unit.target: It will also show how to download dependencies from Azure blob storage.

trans-unit.source: More information about Hudson can be found at <link><linkText>Meet Hudson[]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: More information about Hudson can be found at <link><linkText>Meet Hudson[]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Benefits of using the Blob service
trans-unit.target: Benefits of using the Blob service

trans-unit.source: Benefits of using the Blob service to host your agile development build artifacts include:
trans-unit.target: Benefits of using the Blob service to host your agile development build artifacts include:

trans-unit.source: High availability of your build artifacts and/or downloadable dependencies.
trans-unit.target: High availability of your build artifacts and/or downloadable dependencies.

trans-unit.source: Performance when your Hudson CI solution uploads your build artifacts.
trans-unit.target: Performance when your Hudson CI solution uploads your build artifacts.

trans-unit.source: Performance when your customers and partners download your build artifacts.
trans-unit.target: Performance when your customers and partners download your build artifacts.

trans-unit.source: Control over user access policies, with a choice between anonymous access, expiration-based shared access signature access, private access, etc.
trans-unit.target: Control over user access policies, with a choice between anonymous access, expiration-based shared access signature access, private access, etc.

trans-unit.source: Prequisites
trans-unit.target: Prequisites

trans-unit.source: You will need the following to use the Blob service with your Hudson CI solution:
trans-unit.target: You will need the following to use the Blob service with your Hudson CI solution:

trans-unit.source: A Hudson Continuous Integration solution.
trans-unit.target: A Hudson Continuous Integration solution.

trans-unit.source: If you currently don't have a Hudson CI solution, you can run a Hudson CI solution using the following technique:
trans-unit.target: If you currently don't have a Hudson CI solution, you can run a Hudson CI solution using the following technique:

trans-unit.source: On a Java-enabled machine, download the Hudson WAR from <html></html>.
trans-unit.target: On a Java-enabled machine, download the Hudson WAR from <html></html>.

trans-unit.source: At a command prompt that is opened to the folder that contains the Hudson WAR, run the Hudson WAR.
trans-unit.target: At a command prompt that is opened to the folder that contains the Hudson WAR, run the Hudson WAR.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you have downloaded version 3.1.2:
trans-unit.target: For example, if you have downloaded version 3.1.2:

trans-unit.source: java -jar hudson-3.1.2.war
trans-unit.target: java -jar hudson-3.1.2.war

trans-unit.source: In your browser, open http://localhost:8080/.
trans-unit.target: In your browser, open http://localhost:8080/.

trans-unit.source: This will open the Hudson dashboard.
trans-unit.target: This will open the Hudson dashboard.

trans-unit.source: Upon first use of Hudson, complete the initial setup at http://localhost:8080/.
trans-unit.target: Upon first use of Hudson, complete the initial setup at http://localhost:8080/.

trans-unit.source: After you complete the initial setup, cancel the running instance of the Hudson WAR, start the Hudson WAR again, and re-open the Hudson dashboard, http://localhost:8080/, which you will use to install and configure the Azure Storage plugin.
trans-unit.target: After you complete the initial setup, cancel the running instance of the Hudson WAR, start the Hudson WAR again, and re-open the Hudson dashboard, http://localhost:8080/, which you will use to install and configure the Azure Storage plugin.

trans-unit.source: While a typical Hudson CI solution would be set up to run as a service, running the Hudson war at the command line will be sufficient for this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: While a typical Hudson CI solution would be set up to run as a service, running the Hudson war at the command line will be sufficient for this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: An Azure account. You can sign up for an Azure account at <html></html>.
trans-unit.target: An Azure account. You can sign up for an Azure account at <html></html>.

trans-unit.source: An Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: An Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't already have a storage account, you can create one using the steps at <link><linkText>How to Create a Storage Account[]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you don't already have a storage account, you can create one using the steps at <link><linkText>How to Create a Storage Account[]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Familiarity with the Hudson CI solution is recommended but not required, as the following content will use a basic example to show you the steps needed when using the Blob service as a repository for Hudson CI build artifacts.
trans-unit.target: Familiarity with the Hudson CI solution is recommended but not required, as the following content will use a basic example to show you the steps needed when using the Blob service as a repository for Hudson CI build artifacts.

trans-unit.source: How to use the Blob service with Hudson CI
trans-unit.target: How to use the Blob service with Hudson CI

trans-unit.source: To use the Blob service with Hudson, you'll need to install the Azure Storage plugin, configure the plugin to use your storage account, and then create a post-build action that uploads your build artifacts to your storage account.
trans-unit.target: To use the Blob service with Hudson, you'll need to install the Azure Storage plugin, configure the plugin to use your storage account, and then create a post-build action that uploads your build artifacts to your storage account.

trans-unit.source: These steps are described in the following sections.
trans-unit.target: These steps are described in the following sections.

trans-unit.source: How to install the Azure Storage plugin
trans-unit.target: How to install the Azure Storage plugin

trans-unit.source: Within the Hudson dashboard, click Manage Hudson.
trans-unit.target: Within the Hudson dashboard, click Manage Hudson.

trans-unit.source: In the Manage Hudson page, click Manage Plugins.
trans-unit.target: In the Manage Hudson page, click Manage Plugins.

trans-unit.source: Click the Available tab.
trans-unit.target: Click the Available tab.

trans-unit.source: Click Others.
trans-unit.target: Click Others.

trans-unit.source: In the Artifact Uploaders section, check Microsoft Azure Storage plugin.
trans-unit.target: In the Artifact Uploaders section, check Microsoft Azure Storage plugin.

trans-unit.source: Click Install.
trans-unit.target: Click Install.

trans-unit.source: After the installation is complete, restart Hudson.
trans-unit.target: After the installation is complete, restart Hudson.

trans-unit.source: How to configure the Azure Storage plugin to use your storage account
trans-unit.target: How to configure the Azure Storage plugin to use your storage account

trans-unit.source: Within the Hudson dashboard, click Manage Hudson.
trans-unit.target: Within the Hudson dashboard, click Manage Hudson.

trans-unit.source: In the Manage Hudson page, click Configure System.
trans-unit.target: In the Manage Hudson page, click Configure System.

trans-unit.source: In the Microsoft Azure Storage Account Configuration section:
trans-unit.target: In the Microsoft Azure Storage Account Configuration section:

trans-unit.source: Enter your storage account name, which you can obtain from the Azure portal, <html></html>.
trans-unit.target: Enter your storage account name, which you can obtain from the Azure portal, <html></html>.

trans-unit.source: Enter your storage account key, also obtainable from the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: Enter your storage account key, also obtainable from the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: Use the default value for Blob Service Endpoint URL if you are using the public Azure cloud.
trans-unit.target: Use the default value for Blob Service Endpoint URL if you are using the public Azure cloud.

trans-unit.source: If you are using a different Azure cloud, use the endpoint as specified in the Azure management portal for your storage account.
trans-unit.target: If you are using a different Azure cloud, use the endpoint as specified in the Azure management portal for your storage account.

trans-unit.source: Click Validate storage credentials to validate your storage account.
trans-unit.target: Click Validate storage credentials to validate your storage account.

trans-unit.source: [Optional] If you have additional storage accounts that you want made available to your Hudson CI, click Add more storage accounts.
trans-unit.target: [Optional] If you have additional storage accounts that you want made available to your Hudson CI, click Add more storage accounts.

trans-unit.source: Click Save to save your settings.
trans-unit.target: Click Save to save your settings.

trans-unit.source: How to create a post-build action that uploads your build artifacts to your storage account
trans-unit.target: How to create a post-build action that uploads your build artifacts to your storage account

trans-unit.source: For instruction purposes, first we'll need to create a job that will create several files, and then add in the post-build action to upload the files to your storage account.
trans-unit.target: For instruction purposes, first we'll need to create a job that will create several files, and then add in the post-build action to upload the files to your storage account.

trans-unit.source: Within the Hudson dashboard, click New Job.
trans-unit.target: Within the Hudson dashboard, click New Job.

trans-unit.source: Name the job MyJob, click Build a free-style software job, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: Name the job MyJob, click Build a free-style software job, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: In the Build section of the job configuration, click Add build step and choose Execute Windows batch command.
trans-unit.target: In the Build section of the job configuration, click Add build step and choose Execute Windows batch command.

trans-unit.source: In Command, use the following commands:
trans-unit.target: In Command, use the following commands:

trans-unit.source: In the Post-build Actions section of the job configuration, click Upload artifacts to Microsoft Azure Blob storage.
trans-unit.target: In the Post-build Actions section of the job configuration, click Upload artifacts to Microsoft Azure Blob storage.

trans-unit.source: For Storage Account Name, select the storage account to use.
trans-unit.target: For Storage Account Name, select the storage account to use.

trans-unit.source: For Container Name, specify the container name.
trans-unit.target: For Container Name, specify the container name.

trans-unit.source: (The container will be created if it does not already exist when the build artifacts are uploaded.)
trans-unit.target: (The container will be created if it does not already exist when the build artifacts are uploaded.)

trans-unit.source: You can use environment variables, so for this example enter ${JOB_NAME} as the container name.
trans-unit.target: You can use environment variables, so for this example enter ${JOB_NAME} as the container name.

trans-unit.source: Tip
trans-unit.target: Tip

trans-unit.source: Below the Command section where you entered a script for Execute Windows batch command is a link to the environment variables recognized by Hudson.
trans-unit.target: Below the Command section where you entered a script for Execute Windows batch command is a link to the environment variables recognized by Hudson.

trans-unit.source: Click that link to learn the environment variable names and descriptions.
trans-unit.target: Click that link to learn the environment variable names and descriptions.

trans-unit.source: Note that environment variables that contain special characters, such as the BUILD_URL environment variable, are not allowed as a container name or common virtual path.
trans-unit.target: Note that environment variables that contain special characters, such as the BUILD_URL environment variable, are not allowed as a container name or common virtual path.

trans-unit.source: Click Make new container public by default for this example.
trans-unit.target: Click Make new container public by default for this example.

trans-unit.source: (If you want to use a private container, you'll need to create a shared access signature to allow access.
trans-unit.target: (If you want to use a private container, you'll need to create a shared access signature to allow access.

trans-unit.source: That is beyond the scope of this topic.
trans-unit.target: That is beyond the scope of this topic.

trans-unit.source: You can learn more about shared access signatures at <link><linkText>Creating a Shared Access Signature</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: You can learn more about shared access signatures at <link><linkText>Creating a Shared Access Signature</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: [Optional] Click Clean container before uploading if you want the container to be cleared of contents before build artifacts are uploaded (leave it unchecked if you do not want to clean the contents of the container).
trans-unit.target: [Optional] Click Clean container before uploading if you want the container to be cleared of contents before build artifacts are uploaded (leave it unchecked if you do not want to clean the contents of the container).

trans-unit.source: For List of Artifacts to upload, enter text/*.txt.
trans-unit.target: For List of Artifacts to upload, enter text/*.txt.

trans-unit.source: For Common virtual path for uploaded artifacts, enter ${BUILD\_ID}/${BUILD\_NUMBER}.
trans-unit.target: For Common virtual path for uploaded artifacts, enter ${BUILD\_ID}/${BUILD\_NUMBER}.

trans-unit.source: Click Save to save your settings.
trans-unit.target: Click Save to save your settings.

trans-unit.source: In the Hudson dashboard, click Build Now to run MyJob.
trans-unit.target: In the Hudson dashboard, click Build Now to run MyJob.

trans-unit.source: Examine the console output for status.
trans-unit.target: Examine the console output for status.

trans-unit.source: Status messages for Azure storage will be included in the console output when the post-build action starts to upload build artifacts.
trans-unit.target: Status messages for Azure storage will be included in the console output when the post-build action starts to upload build artifacts.

trans-unit.source: Upon successful completion of the job, you can examine the build artifacts by opening the public blob.
trans-unit.target: Upon successful completion of the job, you can examine the build artifacts by opening the public blob.

trans-unit.source: Login to the Azure management portal, <html></html>.
trans-unit.target: Login to the Azure management portal, <html></html>.

trans-unit.source: Click Storage.
trans-unit.target: Click Storage.

trans-unit.source: Click the storage account name that you used for Hudson.
trans-unit.target: Click the storage account name that you used for Hudson.

trans-unit.source: Click Containers.
trans-unit.target: Click Containers.

trans-unit.source: Click the container named myjob, which is the lowercase version of the job name that you assigned when you created the Hudson job.
trans-unit.target: Click the container named myjob, which is the lowercase version of the job name that you assigned when you created the Hudson job.

trans-unit.source: Container names and blob names are lowercase (and case-sensitive) in Azure storage.
trans-unit.target: Container names and blob names are lowercase (and case-sensitive) in Azure storage.

trans-unit.source: Within the list of blobs for the container named myjob you should see hello.txt and date.txt.
trans-unit.target: Within the list of blobs for the container named myjob you should see hello.txt and date.txt.

trans-unit.source: Copy the URL for either of these items and open it in your browser.
trans-unit.target: Copy the URL for either of these items and open it in your browser.

trans-unit.source: You will see the text file that was uploaded as a build artifact.
trans-unit.target: You will see the text file that was uploaded as a build artifact.

trans-unit.source: Only one post-build action that uploads artifacts to Azure blob storage can be created per job.
trans-unit.target: Only one post-build action that uploads artifacts to Azure blob storage can be created per job.

trans-unit.source: Note that the single post-build action to upload artifacts to Azure blob storage can specify different files (including wildcards) and paths to files within List of Artifacts to upload using a semi-colon as a separator.
trans-unit.target: Note that the single post-build action to upload artifacts to Azure blob storage can specify different files (including wildcards) and paths to files within List of Artifacts to upload using a semi-colon as a separator.

trans-unit.source: For example, if your Hudson build produces JAR files and TXT files in your workspace's build folder, and you want to upload both to Azure blob storage, use the following for the List of Artifacts to upload value: build/\*.jar;build/\*.txt.
trans-unit.target: For example, if your Hudson build produces JAR files and TXT files in your workspace's build folder, and you want to upload both to Azure blob storage, use the following for the List of Artifacts to upload value: build/\*.jar;build/\*.txt.

trans-unit.source: You can also use double-colon syntax to specify a path to use within the blob name.
trans-unit.target: You can also use double-colon syntax to specify a path to use within the blob name.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you want the JARs to get uploaded using binaries in the blob path and the TXT files to get uploaded using notices in the blob path, use the following for the List of Artifacts to upload value: build/\*.jar::binaries;build/\*.txt::notices.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you want the JARs to get uploaded using binaries in the blob path and the TXT files to get uploaded using notices in the blob path, use the following for the List of Artifacts to upload value: build/\*.jar::binaries;build/\*.txt::notices.

trans-unit.source: How to create a build step that downloads from Azure blob storage
trans-unit.target: How to create a build step that downloads from Azure blob storage

trans-unit.source: The following steps show how to configure a build step to download items from Azure blob storage.
trans-unit.target: The following steps show how to configure a build step to download items from Azure blob storage.

trans-unit.source: This would be useful if you want to include items in your build, for example, JARs that you keep in Azure blob storage.
trans-unit.target: This would be useful if you want to include items in your build, for example, JARs that you keep in Azure blob storage.

trans-unit.source: In the Build section of the job configuration, click Add build step and choose Download from Azure Blob storage.
trans-unit.target: In the Build section of the job configuration, click Add build step and choose Download from Azure Blob storage.

trans-unit.source: For Storage account name, select the storage account to use.
trans-unit.target: For Storage account name, select the storage account to use.

trans-unit.source: For Container name, specify the name of the container that has the blobs you want to download.
trans-unit.target: For Container name, specify the name of the container that has the blobs you want to download.

trans-unit.source: You can use environment variables.
trans-unit.target: You can use environment variables.

trans-unit.source: For Blob name, specify the blob name.
trans-unit.target: For Blob name, specify the blob name.

trans-unit.source: You can use environment variables.
trans-unit.target: You can use environment variables.

trans-unit.source: Also, you can use an asterisk, as a wildcard after you specify the initial letter(s) of the blob name.
trans-unit.target: Also, you can use an asterisk, as a wildcard after you specify the initial letter(s) of the blob name.

trans-unit.source: For example, project\* would specify all blobs whose names start with project.
trans-unit.target: For example, project\* would specify all blobs whose names start with project.

trans-unit.source: [Optional] For Download path, specify the path on the Hudson machine where you want to download files from Azure blob storage.
trans-unit.target: [Optional] For Download path, specify the path on the Hudson machine where you want to download files from Azure blob storage.

trans-unit.source: Environment variables can also be used.
trans-unit.target: Environment variables can also be used.

trans-unit.source: (If you do not provide a value for Download path, the files from Azure blob storage will be downloaded to the job's workspace.)
trans-unit.target: (If you do not provide a value for Download path, the files from Azure blob storage will be downloaded to the job's workspace.)

trans-unit.source: If you have additional items you want to download from Azure blob storage, you can create additional build steps.
trans-unit.target: If you have additional items you want to download from Azure blob storage, you can create additional build steps.

trans-unit.source: After you run a build, you can check the build history console output, or look at your download location, to see whether the blobs you expected were successfully downloaded.
trans-unit.target: After you run a build, you can check the build history console output, or look at your download location, to see whether the blobs you expected were successfully downloaded.

trans-unit.source: Components used by the Blob service
trans-unit.target: Components used by the Blob service

trans-unit.source: The following provides an overview of the Blob service components.
trans-unit.target: The following provides an overview of the Blob service components.

trans-unit.source: Storage Account: All access to Azure Storage is done through a storage account.
trans-unit.target: Storage Account: All access to Azure Storage is done through a storage account.

trans-unit.source: This is the highest level of the namespace for accessing blobs.
trans-unit.target: This is the highest level of the namespace for accessing blobs.

trans-unit.source: An account can contain an unlimited number of containers, as long as their total size is under 100TB.
trans-unit.target: An account can contain an unlimited number of containers, as long as their total size is under 100TB.

trans-unit.source: Container: A container provides a grouping of a set of blobs.
trans-unit.target: Container: A container provides a grouping of a set of blobs.

trans-unit.source: All blobs must be in a container.
trans-unit.target: All blobs must be in a container.

trans-unit.source: An account can contain an unlimited number of containers.
trans-unit.target: An account can contain an unlimited number of containers.

trans-unit.source: A container can store an unlimited number of blobs.
trans-unit.target: A container can store an unlimited number of blobs.

trans-unit.source: Blob: A file of any type and size.
trans-unit.target: Blob: A file of any type and size.

trans-unit.source: There are two types of blobs that can be stored in Azure Storage: block and page blobs.
trans-unit.target: There are two types of blobs that can be stored in Azure Storage: block and page blobs.

trans-unit.source: Most files are block blobs.
trans-unit.target: Most files are block blobs.

trans-unit.source: A single block blob can be up to 200GB in size.
trans-unit.target: A single block blob can be up to 200GB in size.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial uses block blobs.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial uses block blobs.

trans-unit.source: Page blobs, another blob type, can be up to 1TB in size, and are more efficient when ranges of bytes in a file are modified frequently.
trans-unit.target: Page blobs, another blob type, can be up to 1TB in size, and are more efficient when ranges of bytes in a file are modified frequently.

trans-unit.source: For more information about blobs, see <link><linkText>Understanding Block Blobs and Page Blobs</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about blobs, see <link><linkText>Understanding Block Blobs and Page Blobs</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: URL format: Blobs are addressable using the following URL format:
trans-unit.target: URL format: Blobs are addressable using the following URL format:

trans-unit.source: http://storageaccount.blob.core.windows.net/container_name/blob_name
trans-unit.target: http://storageaccount.blob.core.windows.net/container_name/blob_name

trans-unit.source: (The format above applies to the public Azure cloud.
trans-unit.target: (The format above applies to the public Azure cloud.

trans-unit.source: If you are using a different Azure cloud, use the endpoint within the Azure management portal to determine your URL endpoint.)
trans-unit.target: If you are using a different Azure cloud, use the endpoint within the Azure management portal to determine your URL endpoint.)

trans-unit.source: In the format above, storageaccount represents the name of your storage account, container_name represents the name of your container, and blob_name represents the name of your blob, respectively.
trans-unit.target: In the format above, storageaccount represents the name of your storage account, container_name represents the name of your container, and blob_name represents the name of your blob, respectively.

trans-unit.source: Within the container name, you can have multiple paths, separated by a forward slash, /.
trans-unit.target: Within the container name, you can have multiple paths, separated by a forward slash, /.

trans-unit.source: The example container name in this tutorial was MyJob, and ${BUILD\_ID}/${BUILD\_NUMBER} was used for the common virtual path, resulting in the blob having a URL of the following form:
trans-unit.target: The example container name in this tutorial was MyJob, and ${BUILD\_ID}/${BUILD\_NUMBER} was used for the common virtual path, resulting in the blob having a URL of the following form:

trans-unit.source: http://example.blob.core.windows.net/myjob/2014-05-01_11-56-22/1/hello.txt
trans-unit.target: http://example.blob.core.windows.net/myjob/2014-05-01_11-56-22/1/hello.txt
